Hillary Clinton has proved her mettle as Secretary of State. In combination with her service as Senator from New York, Clinton has over a decade of top tier experience as a principal in both domestic and foreign policy venues. If she wants to run for president in 2016, Secretary Clinton has surely earned the right.

With respect to Scott Brown, I hope that the people of Massachusetts will remember that his re-election will strengthen the hand of the Senate Republicans in their continuing effort to move America to the right. If Massachusetts voters want a Senator who will support policies and programs championed by the Democratic Party, they would do well to elect a bona fide Democrat.

MJC: I share your sorrow. I am profoundly anguished by the elephant holocaust.  I donate to a couple of African charities that are trying to save elephants (Save the Elephants & the David Sheldrick Wildlife Trust), as well as to other organizations here in the U.S. that work towards helping elephants. I know that I'm not doing enough, and while I post my comments and cries in vain to the Kenyan, Tanzania, Gabonese, Zimbabwe, Congolese, and Ugandan sites, elephants continue to be slaughtered on mass, their beautiful faces butchered and removed by machetes before they're even dead, so that these greedy, despicable thugs can steal every ounce of ivory.  Your assessment is correct - people who care live in fragmented parts of the world, and no one seems to care enough to fight. I cannot tell you how many nights I've wept about this after I read the African blogs and newspapers.  There's a perception that most of the poachers are poor, but many of them are well equipped with high tech weapons and night vision goggles. Even when the poachers are caught, they're usually given small token fines, and they're released with little to no jail time.  Corruption is common, and our elected officials just don't care what's going on over there.

As a Canadian, I am ashamed of my government's actions. If the federal government has solid information of a coming attack on Iran they should do everything in their power to halt it. Such a strike would be illegal under international law, and complicity in such an act is totally unethical.

Part of the problem is that the pugulistic party in power is there with a majority government (more than half the seats in parliament) but with just over one-third of the popular vote (38%) because the more moderate vote is split between the two other parties.

Perhaps Canada's Stephen Harper is just making one exception for President Obama at the instigation of Netanyahu - that he does not always kiss the lower cheeks of American Presidents. Too bad Canadians don't pay enough attention to their government's foreign policies. This latest Iranian caper makes no sense at all. It would be a much better move to pull all Canadian troops out of Afghanistan immediately.

I feel this also, and in the meantime, this catastrophe is crushing my heart. I don't weep here to be on the "right" side of the event.  It is more to find a way to stop it, to say to the universe, "NOT ON OUR WATCH".  An attempt to put forth a time in space that was once worth living.  A fable to believe in one more time.  So many beliefs have died in me in my lifetime.  But this, the images of the heads of the elephants and rhinos chopped off, their babies left orphaned or dead also... I am dying with them every God forsaken day, like everyone else here pouring out their pain.  I post and write and talk and cry, and the Chinese delete immediately, and we are not long for comments on this page.  They will stop.  Andrew, we are at the desert, aren't we.  It's a slow death, and bearing witness to this is the worst of it.

We can't see more than a few thousand years into the past - how many generations is that? Just a blink. A few thousand years into the future the world will be completely different, probably with a lot less diversity of larger animals, maybe people in some form will have their niche but probably not in the 10's of billions. And life will continue. Maybe these future people will engineer life to keep us fed and to keep us engaged with the real world, or maybe creating life will be the future of art.

Elephants might pass, lions, sharks, anything we can eat or use to enhance our potency will be consumed to the last. But life won't ever pass until the sun cooks us crisp. Heck I can't even keep weeds from growing in the cracks on my driveway.

I think we fear creating a world of horror for our children or their children, a world of sun parched land where starvation and thirst and constant struggle for survival replace our struggle to thrive in this society. Just like economic bubbles are part of our nature perhaps we will exceed the capacity of the planet and our ability to engineer the world to produce more and more and the whole thing will come crashing down. But can we really predict what will drive these future generations, or do we project our dreams onto them selfishly? Because we do not want to die of thirst in the desert we will drink too soon, enjoy too much, and then wish we never stepped foot into that place.

Lawrence,

Your letters implies a wide agreement with views about President Obama which you hold but do not state. I am struggling to think what those views are. I disagree with several of your statements, and do not share the view that you imply.

The most general will serve as an example subsuming them all: my position is that the vast majority of white voters in the 2008 election perceived President Obama's political positions correctly. Some agreed with those positions, and some didn't. I believe that those perceptions were accurate and that both the President's positions and the vast majority's perception of those positions have remained pretty much consistent ever since. Some people, now as then, abhor those positions, their holder, or both.

I hope you will see that this forces me to think that your "awakening to the reality, etc." as disingenuous. What you call "his Agenda, stupid" was and is his stated and well understood set of values.

A few days after your letter was published we found that those values were shared in 2012 by a clear majority of the American electorate.

Best wishes,
-dlj.

"Read my lips, no new taxes" was a pledge made by former President George H.W. Bush, "41," during his first campaign for the presidency. It is cited for his not being elected to a second term.  For the author of this article to suggest no one blames (thus holds accountable) politicians today for false statements during their campaigns is nonsense. Voters in America do expect honesty from political candidates as evidenced by Bush, 41's defeat.  In this article, the author has made assumptions regarding race and politics that likely reflect his own political outlook. It is my position that a very high percentage of non-black voters in the general election of 2008, perceived Obama's political viewpoint to be other than what it is.  Today there is a much greater awareness of his personal political views and his political agenda than were known of Candidate Obama's in 2008. If race was not a consideration for the majority of non-white voters in 2008, why would anyone think it is different today? There is nothing embarrassing in recognizing that Obama wasn't what he was perceived to be when casting votes in the last general election based upon what was known about him then. Awakening to the reality of what he is politically about after observing his actions over his first term in office for many voters has been a revelation. It has for me. The economy is still king and all that needs updating is the slogan that personified an earlier election to, "It's his Agenda, stupid."

Instead of acknowledging the crucial role played by Obama at bringing back the badly battered US economy to workable normalcy, or his other foreign policy achievements abroad, any act of assessing his public leadership persona or presidency itself against the magic producing impact of his speeches at the party conventions seems simply churlish. For, having first handed him a difficult legacy of costly wars abroad and fiscal breakdown at home, compounded further by constant legislative disruption, how could the Republicans expect Obama to repeat the same old magic, when the challenges ahead require him to be more nuanced and pragmatic at the job, he is seeking second time? if the Republicans could afford the luxury of being reckless while in government, and wholly negative and obstructionist while in opposition, Obama, with his innate sense of public accountability and awareness of the grave governance challenges, can never be so casual in his public interface now, when he seeks second mandate on the basis of his mixed record of performance in office, and modest promises to fix the problems lying ahead.

I have been cogitating about the Republican position on education. Private schooling is their ideal. Public schooling is at the expense of the taxpayers which in their eye's raises the cost of everything.

But I have been pondering if this point of view has a more fundamental basis. Private schools can and do teach subjects such as creationism and religion, which fosters more followers of the Republican mantra.

Public schools, at least the good ones educate people to think and reason independently. It is not good for the Republicans to have an educated society. Notice the constant attacks by conservatives on the "Liberal Professors" for instance.

Also, those with college degrees vote Democrat more than Republican, and those with advanced degrees even more so. It is beneficial to the Republicans to dumb down society, or at least it appears so.

As for teaching programming and other high tech skills. When these people go to work in the world, what do they do when the plumbing needs fixing, or the electricity quits? Do they get their cars fixed or just reprogram them? who constructs the buildings where they work, buries the cable, or picks up the trash?

No matter the general level of education, it will still take at least 10:1 or more people for support. The first people I always made friends with on a new job were the machinists, not the programmers.

Indeed, we sat on our hands in 2010 when every idiot who could wave a tea bag got elected. The republican tsunami, and the overwhelming confidence it gave the GOP, swept away any hope or chance for change. Now that we are aware just how far the drunk-on-power opposition will go, I hope our hands will go back to pulling levers...

Uh... what? I think this is the best Dowd column I have read in at least a year.

Obama gets my vote, but he never had to work for it. There are some obvious managerial problems in the White House, and I don't wanna see a good president fail due to a smile, B-grade case of hubris. If no one else in his coterie is telling him the hard news, please let him read this installment from MD.

The Preamble does read, "We the People..." Ms. Dowd. The buck does stop with the American people.

Mr. Jefferson, et al, had high hopes for an enlightened, educated, and engaged citizenry. What they got is US.

Despite Harry Truman''s sign, and despite many decades of buck-passers... to lobbyists, to big business, to deep-pocketed cronies... and despite the fact Congress often takes a long time to catch up to our wishes... the buck stops with US.

Barack Obama never promised, "Yes I Can!" - he promised "Yes We Can," and thus far, many of us have learned this lesson: what we can do for our country is to become better informed about issues the "news" media doesn't cover, preferring scandal and created conflict to analysis; better communicators and conveyers of what we learn to others; better teachers, better students, of how the world is being run... and by whom... and to share our understanding of why it is "double-down" time for corporates and the very wealthy to defeat one of the few Presidents who has ever called out their power. (Lest you forget... YouTube is quite helpful.)

A President is not a magic being who suddenly changes the world for the better.

That's a god.

If catechism serves, it's taken one god two millennium-plus to get some people to finally realize it really IS about "treating others as you would have them treat you."

Only some.

And as evidenced by this column, you're not one of them.

Be the change you want to see in the world.

We do not mention what happens to the people who do not get the education, or what happens when there are more educated people than middle class job opportunities. Worldwide social and technological changes have delivered us to a world with an international elite, middle class, and below middle class.

In this world, some of the below middle class people and families will be American, and the condition will tend to be inherited. The level playing field was always sloped, but the slope is getting steeper. Living and being stuck well below middle class used to be a social problem we would work on, giving people a leg up so they could make it. Now it is a permanent feature of the environment, and we only mention it obliquely, by telling individuals how they can escape from it.

We like to think of ourselves as the land of opportunity where anyone who works hard can achieve a modest but decent life. We like to think that we spread the idea, our dream, to other countries. Whether from us or not, they got the idea and tried to become lands of opportunity themselves. Now we are perhaps again first -- the first affluent country to turn its back on that dream.

Our dream is now of a land where it is possible for exceptional people or people born in the right circles, as many as possible, to become rich and ever richer and leave the resulting fortune to their descendants. If that is not our dream, we are out of luck these days, overtaken by the new zeitgeist.

Yeah, we're concerned about voter turnout and enthusiasm, so....let's not get confident??

Confidence is exactly what drives voter turnout and enthusiasm. When you move ahead in the polls, you don't shake your head in disbelief and say, "That can't be true". Unless, of course, you don't want to win.

There's "healthy scepticism", and then there's just a flat-out refusal to accept any good news, to pick it apart and look for some reason to diminish it, to believe that you're doomed no what happens. It's an *unhealthy* scepticism.

On 538 in 2008, there were Obama supporters who, up to the very end, still actively sought out any bad scenario, no matter how unrealistic, that would cause Obama to lose.

It's bloody maddening.

It worries me when the data -- or at least, my take on the data -- strongly reinforces my personal preferences. Especially if my overall "theory of the case" tells me it shouldn't be.

As an Obama supporter, that's kinda where I'm at now: All my experience tells me this should be a razor close race. But everything I've seen since Bill Clinton's speech tells me it no longer is.

In this situation, it's usually a good idea to think hard about what you might be missing. So I'm wondering if the likely voter screens may be exaggerating the Obama Bump (although maybe we should call it the Bubba Bump).

One thing we know is that enthusiasm among Democrats has lagged behind GOP partisans -- and way behind 2008. Until now, this has given the likely voter screens a sizable tilt towards Romney.

But the DNC obviously fired up the base, and I suspect that that, not a swing among undecided voters, accounts for what we're now seeing, as more Democrats and leaners are suddenly counted as likely voters. (Although the fact that Gallup is still using registered voters in its tracker does argue against my theory.)

Could the likely voter screens be overestimating the closing of the enthusiasm gap? In other words, does Romney still deserve a larger-than-normal edge among likely voters vs. registered ones?

Also, what's the decay rate on Democratic enthusiasm? Does it tend to spike higher but fade faster?

I suppose I should just enjoy it while it lasts. But I can't help it: I'm a worrier.

The Democratic bench grows deeper each year... while the team on the other side deals with self-inflicted injuries (both psychic and moral), age, and skewed and shrinking demographics.

Hillary Rodham Clinton has served as First Lady, Senator from New York, and Secretary of State. She would make a great President of the United States.

Whether it will be at the end of Barack Obama's second term, or at the end of Mitt Romney's, has yet to be seen... but personally, I hope the Democrats don't have to waste more time cleaning up a (R) mess -- our country finally has some momentum building, and the great engine of government is moving forward, at last.

And... if we can only keep Obstructionists out of Congress... we might even pick up enough speed to change things before it becomes nearly impossible to do so.
